message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of hypertension, frequent voiding, and headaches, and lab results show elevated PAC:PRA ratio and lack of aldosterone suppression. The CT scan also shows a mass on the left side, indicating primary aldosteronism. Adrenal venous sampling is the recommended next step to confirm the diagnosis and determine whether the mass is a unilateral source of aldosterone production. Left laparoscopic adrenalectomy may be considered if a unilateral source is confirmed. Treatment with eplerenone may be considered as a medical therapy, but adrenal venous sampling is necessary to confirm the diagnosis first. Renal angiogram is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and lab results indicate primary aldosteronism. The CT scan shows a mass on the left side, but further testing is needed for confirmation before surgery. Adrenal venous sampling is the best next step to identify whether the mass is the source of aldosterone excess. Renal angiogram is used for renal artery stenosis. Eplerenone is an aldosterone antagonist that can be used for treatment after confirmation of the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, lab results, and CT scan findings suggest primary aldosteronism. Adrenal venous sampling is the gold standard for distinguishing unilateral and bilateral adrenal causes of primary aldosteronism, and it will guide further treatment options. Renal angiogram is used to evaluate renal artery stenosis as a cause of hypertension but is not relevant in this case. Left laparoscopic adrenalectomy can be considered if a unilateral adrenal cause is confirmed. Eplerenone is a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist that can be used to treat primary aldosteronism but should not be the first option without confirming the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of hypertension with possible hyperaldosteronism. The elevated PAC:PRA ratio and lack of aldosterone suppression with salt loading suggest primary hyperaldosteronism. Adrenal venous sampling is the gold standard test to differentiate unilateral from bilateral disease and guide the decision for surgical resection. Therefore, option (B) is the best next step for this patient.

Renal angiogram is not indicated in this case, and eplerenone is not appropriate until diagnosis is confirmed.

Adrenal venous sampling is the gold standard diagnostic test for this condition and will help determine if the mass is the cause of the aldosterone excess. Renal angiogram is not necessary in this case, left laparoscopic adrenalectomy is a treatment option after the diagnosis is confirmed, and treatment with eplerenone may be considered after the diagnosis is confirmed, but adrenal venous sampling is the next best step.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and lab results suggest primary aldosteronism. The CT scan confirms the presence of an adrenal mass. Adrenal venous sampling is the best next step to determine whether the mass is the source of excessive aldosterone production. Renal angiogram is not necessary and left laparoscopic adrenalectomy is premature without confirming the diagnosis. Eplerenone is a treatment option, but it would not be the best next step without a confirmed diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient shows symptoms consistent with primary aldosteronism, as well as lab findings and a CT scan indicating an adrenal mass. Adrenal venous sampling is the gold standard for localizing the source of aldosterone production and guiding surgical intervention, so it is the best next step for this patient. Renal angiogram and left laparoscopic adrenalectomy are options for treatment, but not the best next step in diagnosis. Treatment with eplerenone may be considered, but it is not the best next step in diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and lab results suggest primary hyperaldosteronism, and the CT scan confirmed an adrenal mass on the left side. Adrenal venous sampling is the most accurate test to confirm unilateral adenoma before surgical intervention. Renal angiogram is not indicated, and left laparoscopic adrenalectomy may not be necessary if the adenoma is found to be nonfunctioning on adrenal venous sampling. Eplerenone is a medication used to treat hyperaldosteronism, but surgical intervention may be necessary in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lab results, including elevated PAC:PRA ratio and lack of aldosterone suppression, along with the CT scan showing a mass on the left side, suggest primary hyperaldosteronism. Adrenal venous sampling is the best next step to differentiate between unilateral and bilateral adrenal hyperplasia, which would affect the management plan. Renal angiogram and left laparoscopic adrenalectomy are not the first-line management options. Treatment with eplerenone can be considered after a definitive diagnosis is made.
